SPEECH.SPEAKER: Valentine.
SPEECH.LINE: Cease to perswade, my louing Protheus;
Home-keeping youth, haue euer homely wits,
Wer't not affection chaines thy tender dayes
To the ſweet glaunces of thy honour’d Loue,
I rather would entreat thy company,
To ſee the wonders of the world abroad,
Then (liuing dully ſluggardiz’d at home)
Weare out thy youth with ſhapeleſſe idleneſſe.
But ſince thou lou'st; loue ſtill, and thriue therein,
Euen as I would, when I to loue begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine adew,
Thinke on thy Protheus, when thou (hap'ly) ſeest
Some rare note-worthy obiect in thy trauaile.
Wish me partaker in thy happineſſe,
When thou do'st meet good hap; and in thy danger,
(If euer danger doe enuiron thee)
Commend thy grieuance to my holy prayers,
For I will be thy beades-man, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: And on a loue-booke pray for my ſucceſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon ſome booke I loue, I'le pray for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: That's on ſome ſhallow Storie of deepe loue,
How yong Leander crost the Hellespont.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: That's a deepe Storie, of a deeper loue,
For he was more then ouer-shoœs in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true; for you are ouer-bootes in loue,
And yet you neuer ſwom the Hellespont.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ouer the Bootes? nay giue me not the Boots.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I will not; for it boots thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: To be in loue; where ſcorne is bought with grones:
Coy looks, with hart-sore ſighes: one fading moments mirth,
With twenty watchfull, weary, tedious nights;
If hap'ly won, perhaps a hapleſſe gaine;
If lost, why then a grieuous labour won;
How euer: but a folly bought with wit,
Or else a wit, by folly vanquished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: So, by your circumstance, you call me foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: So, by your circumstance, I feare you'll proue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis Loue you cauill at, I am not Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue is your master, for he masters you;
And he that is ſo yoked by a foole,
Me thinkes ſhould not be chronicled for wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet Writers ſay; as in the ſweetest Bud,
The eating Canker dwels; ſo eating Loue
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: And Writers ſay; as the mo’t forward Bud
Is eaten by the Canker ere it blow,
Euen ſo by Loue, the yong, and tender wit
Is turn’d to folly, blasting in the Bud,
Loosing his verdure, euen in the prime,
And all the faire effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsaile thee
That art a votary to fond desire?
Once more adieu: my Father at the Road
Expects my comming, there to ſee me ſhip’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And thither will I bring thee Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Protheus, no: Now let vs take our leaue:
To Millaine let me heare from thee by Letters
Of thy ſucceſſe in loue; and what newes else
Betideth here in absence of thy Friend:
And I likewise will visite thee with mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: All happineſſe bechance to thee in Millaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val
SPEECH.LINE: As much to you at home: and ſo farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: He after Honour hunts, I after Loue;
He leaues his friends, to dignifie them more;
I loue my ſelfe, my friends, and all for loue:
Thou Iulia, thou hast metamorphis’d me:
Made me neglect my Studies, loose my time;
Warre with good counsaile; ſet the world at nought;
Made Wit with musing, weake; hart ſick with thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Protheus: 'saue you: ſaw you my Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But now he parted hence to embarque for Millain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Twenty to one then, he is ſhip’d already,
And I haue plaid the Sheepe in loosing him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeede a Sheepe doth very often ſtray,
And if the Shepheard be awhile away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: You conclude that my Master is a Shepheard then, and I Sheepe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then my hornes are his hornes, whether I wake or ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſilly answere, and fitting well a Sheepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: This proues me ſtill a Sheepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: True: and thy Master a Shepheard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall goe hard but ile proue it by another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: The Shepheard ſeekes the Sheepe, and not the
Sheepe the Shepheard; but I ſeeke my Master, and my
Master ſeekes not me: therefore I am no Sheepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sheepe for fodder follow the Shepheard, the Shepheard for foode followes not the Sheepe: thou for wages followest thy Master, thy Master for wages followes not thee: therefore thou art a Sheepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Such another proofe will make me cry baa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But do'st thou heare: gau'st thou my Letter to Iulia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir: I (a lost-Mutton) gaue your Letter to her (a lac’d-Mutton) and ſhe (a lac’d-Mutton) gaue mee (a lost-Mutton) nothing for my labour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's too ſmall a Pasture for ſuch ſtore of
Muttons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: If the ground be ouer-charg’d, you were best ſticke her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, in that you are astray: 'twere best pound you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Sir, leſſe then a pound ſhall ſerue me for car-rying your Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: You mistake; I meane the pound, a Pinfold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: From a pound to a pin? fold it ouer and ouer,
‘Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to your louer

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But what ſaid ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nod-I, why that’s noddy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: You mistooke Sir: I ſay ſhe did nod;
And you aske me if ſhe did nod, and I ſay I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And that ſet together is noddy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Now you haue taken the paines to ſet it toge-ther, take it for your paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, you ſhall haue it for bearing the letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I perceiue I must be faine to beare with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Sir, how doe you beare with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, the letter very orderly,
Hauing nothing but the word noddy for my paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Beshrew me, but you haue a quicke wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet it cannot ouer-take your ſlow purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, open the matter in briefe; what ſaid ſhe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Open your purse, that the money, and the matter may be both at once deliuered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Sir: here is for your paines: what ſaid ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely Sir, I thinke you'll hardly win her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? could'st thou perceiue ſo much from her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I could perceiue nothing at all from her;
No, not ſo much as a ducket for deliuering your letter:
And being ſo hard to me, that brought your minde;
I feare ſhe'll proue as hard to you in telling your minde.
Giue her no token but ſtones, for ſhe's as hard as ſteele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaid ſhe, nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not ſo much as take this for thy pains: To testifie your bounty, I thank you, you haue cestern’d me; In requital whereof, henceforth, carry your letters your ſelfe; And ſo Sir, I'le commend you to my Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, be gone, to ſaue your Ship from wrack,
Which cannot perish hauing thee aboarde,
Being destin’d to a drier death on ſhore:
I must goe ſend ſome better Meſſenger,
I feare my Iulia would not daigne my lines,
Receiuing them from ſuch a worthleſſe post.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſay Lucetta (now we are alone)
Would'st thou then counsaile me to fall in loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam, ſo you ſtumble not vnheedfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all the faire resort of Gentlemen,
That euery day with par'le encounter me,
In thy opinion which is worthiest loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you repeat their names, ile ſhew my minde,
According to my ſhallow ſimple ſkill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: What thinkst thou of the faire ſir Eglamoure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: As of a Knight, well-spoken, neat, and fine;
But were I you, he neuer ſhould be mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Well of his wealth; but of himselfe, ſo, ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: What think'st thou of the gentle Protheus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord, Lord: to ſee what folly raignes in vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? what meanes this paſſion at his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon deare Madam, ‘tis a paſſing ſhame,
That I (vnworthy body as I am)
Should censure thus on louely Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Why not on Protheus, as of all the rest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Then thus: of many good, I thinke him best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Your reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no other but a womans reason:
I thinke him ſo, because I thinke him ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And would'st thou haue me cast my loue on him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: I: if you thought your loue not cast away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Why he, of all the rest, hath neuer mou’d me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet he, of all the rest, I thinke best loues ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: His little ſpeaking, ſhewes his loue but ſmall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Fire that’s closest kept, burnes mo’t of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: They doe not loue, that doe not ſhew their loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, they loue least, that let men know their loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I knew his minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Peruse this paper Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: To Iulia: ſay, from whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: That the Contents will ſhew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, ſay: who gaue it thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentines page: & ſent I think from Protheus;
He would haue giuen it you, but I being in the way,
Did in your name receiue it: pardon the fault I pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Now (by my modesty) a goodly Broker:
Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
To whisper, and conspire against my youth?
Now trust me, ‘tis an office of great worth,
And you an officer fit for the place:
There: take the paper: ſee it be return’d,
Or else returne no more into my ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: To plead for loue, deserues more fee, then hate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Will ye be gon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu
SPEECH.LINE: That you may ruminate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet I would I had ore-look’d the Letter;
It were a ſhame to call her backe againe,
And pray her to a fault, for which I chid her.
What 'foole is ſhe, that knowes I am a Maid,
And would not force the letter to my view?
Since Maides, in modesty, ſay no, to that,
Which they would haue the profferer construe, I.
Fie, fie: how way-ward is this foolish loue;
That (like a testie Babe) will ſcratch the Nurse,
And presently, all humbled kiſſe the Rod?
How churlishly, I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly, I would haue had her here?
How angerly I taught my brow to frowne,
When inward ioy enforc’d my heart to ſmile?
My pennance is, to call Lucetta backe
And aske remiſſion, for my folly past.
What hœ: Lucetta.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: What would your Ladiship?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't neere dinner time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were,
That you might kill your ſtomacke on your meat,
And not vpon your Maid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: What is't that you
Tooke vp ſo gingerly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Why didst thou ſtoope then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: To take a paper vp, that I let fall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And is that paper nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing concerning me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let it lye, for those that it concernes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, it will not lye where it concernes,
Vnleſſe it haue a false Interpreter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Some loue of yours, hath writ to you in Rime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: That I might ſing it (Madam) to a tune:
Giue me a Note, your Ladiship can ſet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: As little by ſuch toyes, as may be poſſible:
Best ſing it to the tune of Light O, Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is too heauy for ſo light a tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauy? belike it hath ſome burden then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: I: and melodious were it, would you ſing it,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: And why not you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot reach ſo high.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's ſee your Song:
How now Minion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Keepe tune there ſtill; ſo you will ſing it out:
And yet me thinkes I do not like this tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: You doe not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: No (Madam) tis too ſharpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: You (Minion) are too ſaucie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, now you are too flat;
And marre the concord, with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a Meane to fill your Song.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: The meane is dround with you vnruly base.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeede I bid the base for Protheus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: This babble ſhall not henceforth trouble me;
Here is a coile with protestation:
Goe, get you gone: and let the papers lye:
You would be fingring them, to anger me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: She makes it ſtra[n]ge, but ſhe would be best pleas’d
To be ſo angred with another Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, would I were ſo angred with the ſame:
Oh hatefull hands, to teare ſuch louing words;
Iniurious Waspes, to feede on ſuch ſweet hony,
And kill the Bees that yeelde it, with your ſtings;
Ile kiſſe each ſeuerall paper, for amends:
Looke, here is writ, kinde Iulia: vnkinde Iulia,
As in reuenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruzing-stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdaine.
And here is writ, Loue wounded Protheus.
Poore wounded name: my bosome, as a bed,
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly heal’d;
And thus I ſearch it with a ſoueraigne kiſſe.
But twice, or thrice, was Protheus written downe:
Be calme (good winde) blow not a word away,
Till I haue found each letter, in the Letter,
Except mine own name: That, ſome whirle-winde beare
Vnto a ragged, fearefull, hanging Rocke,
And throw it thence into the raging Sea.
Lœ, here in one line is his name twice writ:
Poore forlorne Protheus, paſſionate Protheus:
To the ſweet Iulia: that ile teare away:
And yet I will not, ſith ſo prettily
He couples it, to his complaining Names;
Thus will I fold them, one vpon another;
Now kiſſe, embrace, contend, doe what you will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam: dinner is ready: and your father ſtaies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let vs goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: What, ſhall these papers lye, like Tel-tales here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: If you respect them; best to take them vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I was taken vp, for laying them downe.
Yet here they ſhall not lye, for catching cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee you haue a months minde to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lu.
SPEECH.LINE: I (Madam) you may ſay what ſights you ſee;
I ſee things too, although you iudge I winke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, wilt please you goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me Panthino, what ſad talke was that,
Wherewith my brother held you in the Cloyster?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas of his Nephew Protheus, your Sonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? what of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: He wondred that your Lordship
Would ſuffer him, to ſpend his youth at home,
While other men, of ſlender reputation
Put forth their Sonnes, to ſeeke preferment out.
Some to the warres, to try their fortune there;
Some, to discouer Islands farre away:
Some, to the ſtudious Vniuersities;
For any, or for all these exercises,
He ſaid, that Protheus, your ſonne, was meet;
And did request me, to importune you
To let him ſpend his time no more at home;
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In hauing knowne no trauaile in his youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
Whereon, this month I haue bin hamering.
I haue consider’d well, his loſſe of time,
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tryed, and tutord in the world:
Experience is by industry atchieu’d,
And perfected by the ſwift course of time:
Then tell me, whether were I best to ſend him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke your Lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthfull Valentine,
Attends the Emperour in his royall Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere good, I thinke, your Lordship ſent him
(thither,
There ſhall he practise Tilts, and Turnaments;
Heare ſweet discourse, conuerse with Noble-men,
And be in eye of euery Exercise
Worthy his youth, and nobleneſſe of birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I like thy counsaile: well hast thou aduis’d:
And that thou maist perceiue how well I like it,
The execution of it ſhall make knowne;
Euen with the ſpeediest expedition,
I will dispatch him to the Emperors Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,
With other Gentlemen of good esteeme
Are iournying, to ſalute the Emperor,
And to commend their ſeruice to his will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Good company: with them ſhall Protheus go:
And in good time: now will we breake with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Loue, ſweet lines, ſweet life,
Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
Here is her oath for loue, her honors paune;
O that our Fathers would applaud our loues
To ſeale our happineſſe with their consents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauenly Iulia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? What Letter are you reading there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: May't please your Lordship, ‘tis a word or two
Of commendations ſent from Valentine;
Deliuer’d by a friend, that came from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Lend me the Letter: Let me ſee what newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no newes (my Lord) but that he writes
How happily he liues, how well-belou’d,
And daily graced by the Emperor;
Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And how ſtand you affected to his wish?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: As one relying on your Lordships will,
And not depending on his friendly wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: My will is ſomething ſorted with his wish:
Muse not that I thus ſodainly proceed;
For what I will, I will, and there an end:
I am resolu’d, that thou ſhalt ſpend ſome time
With Valentinus, in the Emperors Court:
What maintenance he from his friends receiues,
Like exhibition thou ſhalt haue from me,
To morrow be in readineſſe, to goe,
Excuse it not: for I am peremptory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord I cannot be ſo ſoone prouided,
Please you deliberate a day or two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Look what thou want'st ſhalbe ſent after thee:
No more of ſtay: to morrow thou must goe;
Come on Panthino; you ſhall be imployd,
To hasten on his Expedition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus haue I ſhund the fire, for feare of burning,
And drench’d me in the ſea, where I am drown’d.
I fear’d to ſhew my Father Iulias Letter,
Least he ſhould take exceptions to my loue,
And with the vantage of mine owne excuse
Hath he excepted mo’t against my loue.
Oh, how this ſpring of loue resembleth
The vncertaine glory of an Aprill day,
Which now ſhewes all the beauty of the Sun,
And by and by a clowd takes all away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Protheus, your Fathers call's for you,
He is in hast, therefore I pray you go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this it is: my heart accords thereto,
And yet a thousand times it anſwer's no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, your Gloue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Valen.
SPEECH.LINE: Not mine: my Gloues are on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then this may be yours: for this is but one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Let me ſee: I, giue it me, it's mine:
Sweet Ornament, that deckes a thing diuine,
Ah Siluia, Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam Siluia: Madam Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Sirha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee is not within hearing Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, who bad you call her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Your worship ſir, or else I mistooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: you'll ſtill be too forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet I was last chidden for being too ſlow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe to, ſir, tell me: do you know Madam Siluia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee that your worship loues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, how know you that I am in loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry by these ſpeciall markes: first, you haue learn’d (like Sir Protheus) to wreath your Armes like a Male-content: to rellish a Loue-song, like a Robin-red-breast: to walke alone like one that had the pestilence: to ſigh, like a Schoole-boy that had lost his A.B.C. to weep like a yong wench that had buried her Grandam: to fast, like one that takes diet: to watch, like one that feares robbing: to ſpeake puling, like a beggar at Hal-low-Maſſe: You were wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cocke; when you walk’d, to walke like one of the Lions: when you fasted, it was presently after dinner: when you look’d ſadly, it was for want of money: And now you are Metamorphis’d with a Mistris, that when I looke on you, I can hardly thinke you my Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Are all these things perceiu’d in me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: They are all perceiu’d without ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Without me? they cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Without you? nay, that’s certaine: for with-out you were ſo ſimple, none else would: but you are ſo without these follies, that these follies are within you, and ſhine through you like the water in an Vrinall: that not an eye that ſees you, but is a Physician to comment on your Malady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: But tell me: do'st thou know my Lady Siluia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee that you gaze on ſo, as ſhe ſits at ſupper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Hast thou obseru’d that? euen ſhe I meane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, I know her not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet know'st her not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe not hard-fauour’d, ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo faire (boy) as well fauour’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I know that well enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: What dost thou know?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhee is not ſo faire, as (of you) well-fa-uourd?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane that her beauty is exquisite,
But her fauour infinite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: That's because the one is painted, and the o-ther out of all count.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How painted? and how out of count?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, ſo painted to make her faire, that no man counts of her beauty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How esteem'st thou me? I account of her beauty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: You neuer ſaw her ſince ſhe was deform’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How long hath ſhe beene deform’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Euer ſince you lou’d her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue lou’d her euer ſince I ſaw her,
And ſtill I ſee her beautifull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: If you loue her, you cannot ſee her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Because Loue is blinde: O that you had mine eyes, or your owne eyes had the lights they were wont to haue, when you chidde at Sir Protheus, for going vn-garter’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould I ſee then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Your owne present folly, and her paſſing de-formitie: for hee beeing in loue, could not ſee to garter his hose; and you, beeing in loue, cannot ſee to put on your hose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Belike (boy) then you are in loue, for last morning
You could not ſee to wipe my ſhoœs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: True ſir: I was in loue with my bed, I thanke you, you ſwing’d me for my loue, which makes mee the bolder to chide you, for yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: In conclusion, I ſtand affected to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you were ſet, ſo your affection would cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Last night ſhe enioyn’d me,
To write ſome lines to one ſhe loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: And haue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Are they not lamely writt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No (Boy) but as well as I can do them:
Peace, here ſhe comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh excellent motion; oh exceeding Puppet:
Now will he interpret to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam & Mistres, a thousand good-morrows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, 'giue ye-good-ev'n: heer's a million of manners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentine, and ſeruant, to you two thousand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhould giue her interest: & ſhe giues it him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: As you inioynd me; I haue writ your Letter
Vnto the ſecret, nameles friend of yours:
Which I was much vnwilling to proceed in,
But for my duty to your Ladiship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you (gentle Seruant) ‘tis very Clerkly done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Now trust me (Madam) it came hardly-off:
For being ignorant to whom it goes,
I writ at randome, very doubtfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Perchance you think too much of ſo much pains?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No (Madam) ſo it ſteed you, I will write
(Please you command) a thousand times as much:
And yet —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: A pretty period: well: I gheſſe the ſequell;
And yet I will not name it: and yet I care not.
And yet, take this againe: and yet I thanke you:
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet you will: and yet, another yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes your Ladiship?
Doe you not like it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, yes: the lines are very queintly writ,
But (since vnwillingly) take them againe.
Nay, take them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, they are for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Silu.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I: you writ them Sir, at my request,
But I will none of them: they are for you:
I would haue had them writ more mouingly:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you, Ile write your Ladiship another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: And when it's writ: for my ſake read it ouer,
And if it please you, ſo: if not: why ſo:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: If it please me, (Madam?) what then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Why if it please you, take it for your labour;
And ſo good-morrow Seruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Iest vnseene: inscrutible: inuisible,
As a nose on a mans face, or a Wethercocke on a ſteeple:
My Master ſues to her: and ſhe hath taught her Sutor,
He being her Pupill, to become her Tutor.
Oh excellent deuise, was there euer heard a better?
That my master being ſcribe,
To himselfe ſhould write the Letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Sir?
What are you reasoning with your ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay: I was riming: ‘tis you y haue the reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: To doe what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: To be a Spokes-man from Madam Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: To whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: To your ſelfe: why, ſhe wœs you by a figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: What figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: By a Letter, I ſhould ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhe hath not writ to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: What need ſhe,
When ſhee hath made you write to your ſelfe?
Why, doe you not perceiue the iest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No, beleeue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: No beleeuing you indeed ſir:
But did you perceiue her earnest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: She gaue me none, except an angry word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhe hath giuen you a Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: That's the Letter I writ to her friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: And y letter hath ſhe deliuer’d, & there an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were no worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile warrant you, ‘tis as well:
For often haue you writ to her: and ſhe in modesty,
Or else for want of idle time, could not againe reply,
Or fearing els ſome meſſe[n]ger, y might her mind discouer
Her ſelf hath taught her Loue himself, to write vnto her louer.
All this I ſpeak in print, for in print I found it.
Why muse you ſir, ‘tis dinner time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue dyn’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but hearken ſir: though the Cameleon Loue can feed on the ayre, I am one that am nourish’d by my victuals; and would faine haue meate: oh bee not like your Mistreſſe, be moued, be moued. Exeunt. Scœna ſecunda.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue patience, gentle Iulia:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I must where is no remedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: When poſſibly I can, I will returne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: If you turne not: you will return the ſooner:
Keepe this remembrance for thy Iulia's ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then wee'll make exchange;
Here, take you this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſeale the bargaine with a holy kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is my hand, for my true constancie:
And when that howre ore-slips me in the day,
Wherein I ſigh not (Iulia) for thy ſake,
The next ensuing howre, ſome foule mischance
Torment me for my Loues forgetfulneſſe:
My father ſtaies my comming: answere not:
The tide is now; nay, not thy tide of teares,
That tide will ſtay me longer then I ſhould,
Iulia, farewell: what, gon without a word?
I, ſo true loue ſhould doe: it cannot ſpeake,
For truth hath better deeds, then words to grace it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panth.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Protheus: you are ſtaid for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe: I come, I come:
Alas, this parting ſtrikes poore Louers dumbe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Launce.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, 'twill bee this howre ere I haue done weeping: all the kinde of the Launces, haue this very fault: I haue receiu’d my proportion, like the prodigious Sonne, and am going with Sir Protheus to the Imperialls Court: I thinke Crab my dog, be the ſowrest natured dogge that liues: My Mother weeping: my Father wayling: my Sister crying: our Maid howling: our Catte wringing her hands, and all our house in a great perplexitie, yet did not this cruell-hearted Curre ſhedde one teare: he is a ſtone, a very pibble ſtone, and has no more pitty in him then a dogge: a Iew would haue wept to haue ſeene our parting: why my Grandam hauing no eyes, looke you, wept her ſelfe blinde at my parting: nay, Ile ſhew you the manner of it. This ſhoœ is my fa-ther: no, this left ſhoœ is my father; no, no, this left ſhoœ is my mother: nay, that cannot bee ſo neyther: yes; it is ſo, it is ſo: it hath the worser ſole: this ſhoœ with the hole in it, is my mother: and this my father: a veng'ance on't, there ‘tis: Now ſir, this ſtaffe is my ſi-ster: for, looke you, ſhe is as white as a lilly, and as ſmall as a wand: this hat is Nan our maid: I am the dogge: no, the dogge is himselfe, and I am the dogge: oh, the dogge is me, and I am my ſelfe: I; ſo, ſo: now come I to my Father; Father, your bleſſing: now ſhould not the ſhoœ ſpeake a word for weeping: now ſhould I kiſſe my Father; well, hee weepes on: Now come I to my Mother: Oh that ſhe could ſpeake now, like a would-woman: well, I kiſſe her: why there ‘tis; heere's my mothers breath vp and downe: Now come I to my ſister; marke the moane ſhe makes: now the dogge all this while ſheds not a teare: nor ſpeakes a word: but ſee how I lay the dust with my teares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panth.
SPEECH.LINE: Launce, away, away: a Boord: thy Master is ſhip’d, and thou art to post after with oares; what’s the matter? why weep'st thou man? away aſſe, you'l loose the Tide, if you tarry any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laun.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter if the tide were lost, for it is the vnkindest Tide, that euer any man tide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panth.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the vnkindest tide?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, he that’s tide here, Crab my dog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pant.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, man: I meane thou'lt loose the flood, and in loosing the flood, loose thy voyage, and in loosing thy voyage, loose thy Master, and in loosing thy Master, loose thy ſeruice, and in loosing thy ſeruice: — why dost thou ſtop my mouth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laun.
SPEECH.LINE: For feare thou ſhouldst loose thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panth.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſhould I loose my tongue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laun.
SPEECH.LINE: In thy Tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panth.
SPEECH.LINE: In thy Taile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laun.
SPEECH.LINE: Loose the Tide, and the voyage, and the Ma-ster, and the Seruice, and the tide: why man, if the Riuer were drie, I am able to fill it with my teares: if the winde were downe, I could driue the boate with my ſighes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panth.
SPEECH.LINE: Come: come away man, I was ſent to call thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir: call me what thou dar'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pant.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou goe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laun.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will goe.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Valentine, Siluia, Thurio, Speed, Duke, Protheus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Seruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, Sir Thurio frownes on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I Boy, it's for loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: Not of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Of my Mistreſſe then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere good you knockt him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Seruant, you are ſad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, Madam, I ſeeme ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Seeme you that you are not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Hap'ly I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: So doe Counterfeyts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: So doe you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſeeme I that I am not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: What instance of the contrary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Your folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: And how quoat you my folly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I quoat it in your Ierkin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: My Ierkin is a doublet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, Ile double your folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: How?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: What, angry, Sir Thurio, do you change colour?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue him leaue, Madam, he is a kind of Camelion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: That hath more minde to feed on your bloud, then liue in your ayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue ſaid Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir, and done too for this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it wel ſir, you alwaies end ere you begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: A fine volly of words, gentleme[n], & quickly ſhot off

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis indeed, Madam, we thank the giuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Who is that Seruant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Your ſelfe (sweet Lady) for you gaue the fire,
Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your Ladiships lookes,
And ſpends what he borrowes kindly in your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, if you ſpend word for word with me, I ſhall make your wit bankrupt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well ſir: you haue an Exchequer of words,
And I thinke, no other treasure to giue your followers:
For it appeares by their bare Liueries
That they liue by your bare words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: No more, gentlemen, no more:
Here comes my father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, daughter Siluia, you are hard beset.
Sir Valentine, your father is in good health,
What ſay you to a Letter from your friends
Of much good newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I will be thankfull,
To any happy meſſenger from thence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Know ye Don Antonio, your Countriman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I, my good Lord, I know the Gentleman
To be of worth, and worthy estimation,
And not without desert ſo well reputed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he not a Sonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I, my good Lord, a Son, that well deserues
The honor, and regard of ſuch a father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: You know him well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I knew him as my ſelfe: for from our Infancie
We haue conuerst, and ſpent our howres together,
And though my ſelfe haue beene an idle Trewant,
Omitting the ſweet benefit of time
To cloath mine age with Angel-like perfection:
Yet hath Sir Protheus (for that’s his name)
Made vse, and faire aduantage of his daies:
His yeares but yong, but his experience old:
His head vn-mellowed, but his Iudgement ripe;
And in a word (for far behinde his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow.)
He is compleat in feature, and in minde,
With all good grace, to grace a Gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Beshrew me ſir, but if he make this good
He is as worthy for an Empreſſe loue,
As meet to be an Emperors Councellor:
Well, Sir: this Gentleman is come to me
With Commendation from great Potentates,
And heere he meanes to ſpend his time a while,
I thinke ‘tis no vn-welcome newes to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Should I haue wish’d a thing, it had beene he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome him then according to his worth:
Siluia, I ſpeake to you, and you Sir Thurio,
For Valentine, I need not cite him to it,
I will ſend him hither to you presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the Gentleman I told your Ladiship
Had come along with me, but that his Mistreſſe
Did hold his eyes, lockt in her Christall lookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Be-like that now ſhe hath enfranchis’d them
Vpon ſome other pawne for fealty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay ſure, I thinke ſhe holds them prisoners ſtil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then he ſhould be blind, and being blind
How could he ſee his way to ſeeke out you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Lady, Loue hath twenty paire of eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thur.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay that Loue hath not an eye at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſee ſuch Louers, Thurio, as your ſelfe,
Vpon a homely obiect, Loue can winke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue done, haue done: here comes y gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome, deer Protheus: Mistris, I beseech you
Confirme his welcome, with ſome ſpeciall fauor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: His worth is warrant for his welcome hether,
If this be he you oft haue wish’d to heare from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris, it is: ſweet Lady, entertaine him
To be my fellow-seruant to your Ladiship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Too low a Mistres for ſo high a ſeruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, ſweet Lady, but too meane a ſeruant
To haue a looke of ſuch a worthy a Mistreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Leaue off discourse of disabilitie:
Sweet Lady, entertaine him for your Seruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My dutie will I boast of, nothing else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: And dutie neuer yet did want his meed.
Seruant, you are welcome to a worthleſſe Mistreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile die on him that ſaies ſo but your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: That you are welcome?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: That you are worthleſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thur.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, my Lord your father wold ſpeak with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: I wait vpon his pleasure: Come Sir Thurio,
Goe with me: once more, new Seruant welcome;
Ile leaue you to confer of home affaires,
When you haue done, we looke too heare from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'll both attend vpon your Ladiship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Now tell me: how do al from whence you came?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Your frends are wel, & haue the[m] much co[m]mended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: And how doe yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I left them all in health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How does your Lady? & how thriues your loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My tales of Loue were wont to weary you,
I know you ioy not in a Loue-discourse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I Protheus, but that life is alter’d now,
I haue done pennance for contemning Loue,
Whose high emperious thoughts haue punish’d me
With bitter fasts, with penitentiall grones,
With nightly teares, and daily hart-sore ſighes,
For in reuenge of my contempt of loue,
Loue hath chas’d ſleepe from my enthralled eyes,
And made them watchers of mine owne hearts ſorrow.
O gentle Protheus, Loue's a mighty Lord,
And hath ſo humbled me, as I confeſſe
There is no wœ to his correction,
Nor to his Seruice, no ſuch ioy on earth:
Now, no discourse, except it be of loue:
Now can I breake my fast, dine, ſup, and ſleepe,
Vpon the very naked name of Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye:
Was this the Idoll, that you worship ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen She; and is ſhe not a heauenly Saint?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No; But ſhe is an earthly Paragon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Call her diuine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not flatter her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: O flatter me: for Loue delights in praises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: When I was ſick, you gaue me bitter pils,
And I must minister the like to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſpeake the truth by her; if not diuine,
Yet let her be a principalitie,
Soueraigne to all the Creatures on the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Except my Mistreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet: except not any,
Except thou wilt except against my Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I not reason to prefer mine owne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will help thee to prefer her to:
Shee ſhall be dignified with this high honour,
To beare my Ladies traine, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to ſteale a kiſſe,
And of ſo great a fauor growing proud,
Disdaine to roote the Sommer-swelling flowre,
And make rough winter euerlastingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Valentine, what Bragadisme is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me (Protheus) all I can is nothing,
To her, whose worth, make other worthies nothing;
Shee is alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let her alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Not for the world: why man, ſhe is mine owne,
And I as rich in hauing ſuch a Iewell
As twenty Seas, if all their ſand were pearle,
The water, Nectar, and the Rocks pure gold.
Forgiue me, that I doe not dreame on thee,
Because thou ſeest me doate vpon my loue:
My foolish Riuall that her Father likes
(Onely for his poſſeſſions are ſo huge)
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For Loue (thou know'st is full of iealousie.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhe loues you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and we are betroathd: nay more, our mariage howre,
With all the cunning manner of our flight
Determin’d of: how I must climbe her window,
The Ladder made of Cords, and all the means
Plotted, and 'greed on for my happineſſe.
Good Protheus goe with me to my chamber,
In these affaires to aid me with thy counsaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe on before: I ſhall enquire you forth:
I must vnto the Road, to dis-embarque
Some neceſſaries, that I needs must vse,
And then Ile presently attend you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val
SPEECH.LINE: Will you make haste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I will.
Euen as one heate, another heate expels,
Or as one naile, by ſtrength driues out another.
So the remembrance of my former Loue
Is by a newer obiect quite forgotten,
It is mine, or Valentines praise?
Her true perfection, or my false transgreſſion?
That makes me reasonleſſe, to reason thus?
Shee is faire: and ſo is Iulia that I loue,
(That I did loue, for now my loue is thaw’d,
Which like a waxen Image 'gainst a fire
Beares no impreſſion of the thing it was.)
Me thinkes my zeale to Valentine is cold,
And that I loue him not as I was wont:
O, but I loue his Lady too-too much,
And that’s the reason I loue him ſo little.
How ſhall I doate on her with more aduice,
That thus without aduice begin to loue her?
‘Tis but her picture I haue yet beheld,
And that hath dazel’d my reasons light:
But when I looke on her perfections,
There is no reason, but I ſhall be blinde.
If I can checke my erring loue, I will,
If not, to compaſſe her Ile vse my ſkill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Launce, by mine honesty welcome to Padua.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laun.
SPEECH.LINE: Forsweare not thy ſelfe, ſweet youth, for I am not welcome. I reckon this alwaies, that a man is neuer vndon till hee be hang’d, nor neuer welcome to a place, till ſome certaine ſhot be paid, and the Hosteſſe ſay wel-come. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: Come-on you mad-cap: Ile to the Ale-house with you presently; where, for one ſhot of fiue pence, thou ſhalt haue fiue thousand welcomes: But ſirha, how did thy Master part with Madam Iulia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry after they cloas’d in earnest, they parted very fairely in iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhall ſhe marry him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: How then? ſhall he marry her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: No, neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: What, are they broken?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: No; they are both as whole as a fish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then, how ſtands the matter with them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry thus, when it ſtands well with him, it ſtands well with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: What an aſſe art thou, I vnderstand thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: What a blocke art thou, that thou canst not?
My ſtaffe vnderstands me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: What thou ſaist?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and what I do too: looke thee, Ile but leane, and my ſtaffe vnderstands me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſtands vnder thee indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, ſtand-vnder: and vnder-stand is all one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: But tell me true, wil't be a match?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Aske my dogge, if he ſay I, it will: if hee ſay no, it will: if hee ſhake his taile, and ſay nothing, it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: The conclusion is then, that it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt neuer get ſuch a ſecret from me, but by a parable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well that I get it ſo: but Launce, how ſaist thou that that my master is become a notable Louer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer knew him otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: Then how?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: A notable Lubber: as thou reportest him to bee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, thou whorson Aſſe, thou mistak'st me,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Foole, I meant not thee, I meant thy
Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee, my Master is become a hot Louer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I tell thee, I care not, though hee burne himselfe in Loue. If thou wilt goe with me to the Ale-house: if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Iew, and not worth the name of a Christian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Because thou hast not ſo much charity in thee as to goe to the Ale with a Christian: Wilt thou goe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spee.
SPEECH.LINE: At thy ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: To leaue my Iulia; ſhall I be forsworne?
To loue faire Siluia; ſhall I be forsworne?
To wrong my friend, I ſhall be much forsworne.
And ev'n that Powre which gaue me first my oath
Prouokes me to this three-fold periurie.
Loue bad mee ſweare, and Loue bids me for-sweare;
O ſweet-suggesting Loue, if thou hast ſin’d,
Teach me (thy tempted ſubiect) to excuse it.
At first I did adore a twinkling Starre,
But now I worship a celestiall Sunne:
Vn-heedfull vowes may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit, that wants resolued will,
To learne his wit, t’ exchange the bad for better;
Fie, fie, vnreuerend tongue, to call her bad,
Whose ſoueraignty ſo oft thou hast preferd,
With twenty thousand ſoule-confirming oathes.
I cannot leaue to loue; and yet I doe:
But there I leaue to loue, where I ſhould loue.
Iulia I loose, and Valentine I loose,
If I keepe them, I needs must loose my ſelfe:
If I loose them, thus finde I by their loſſe,
For Valentine, my ſelfe: for Iulia, Siluia.
I to my ſelfe am deerer then a friend,
For Loue is ſtill mo’t precious in it ſelfe,
And Siluia (witneſſe heauen that made her faire)
Shewes Iulia but a ſwarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Iulia is aliue,
Remembring that my Loue to her is dead.
And Valentine Ile hold an Enemie,
Ayming at Siluia as a ſweeter friend.
I cannot now proue constant to my ſelfe,
Without ſome treachery vs’d to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a Corded-ladder
To climbe celestiall Siluia's chamber window,
My ſelfe in counsaile his competitor.
Now presently Ile giue her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight:
Who (all inrag’d) will banish Valentine:
For Thurio he intends ſhall wed his daughter,
But Valentine being gon, Ile quickely croſſe
By ſome ſlie tricke, blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Loue lend me wings, to make my purpose ſwift
As thou hast lent me wit, to plot this drift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Counsaile, Lucetta, gentle girle aſſist me,
And eu'n in kinde loue, I doe coniure thee,
Who art the Table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly Character’d, and engrau’d,
To leſſon me, and tell me ſome good meane
How with my honour I may vndertake
A iourney to my louing Protheus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, the way is wearisome and long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: A true-deuoted Pilgrime is not weary
To measure Kingdomes with his feeble ſteps,
Much leſſe ſhall ſhe that hath Loues wings to flie,
And when the flight is made to one ſo deere,
Of ſuch diuine perfection as Sir Protheus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Better forbeare, till Protheus make returne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, know'st y not, his looks are my ſoules food?
Pitty the dearth that I haue pined in,
By longing for that food ſo long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of Loue,
Thou wouldst as ſoone goe kindle fire with ſnow
As ſeeke to quench the fire of Loue with words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe not ſeeke to quench your Loues hot fire,
But qualifie the fires extreame rage,
Lest it ſhould burne aboue the bounds of reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: The more thou dam'st it vp, the more it burnes:
The Current that with gentle murmure glides
(Thou know'st) being ſtop’d, impatiently doth rage:
But when his faire course is not hindered,
He makes ſweet musicke with th’ enameld ſtones,
Giuing a gentle kiſſe to euery ſedge
He ouer-taketh in his pilgrimage.
And ſo by many winding nookes he ſtraies
With willing ſport to the wilde Ocean.
Then let me goe, and hinder not my course:
Ile be as patient as a gentle ſtreame,
And make a pastime of each weary ſtep,
Till the last ſtep haue brought me to my Loue,
And there Ile rest, as after much turmoile
A bleſſed ſoule doth in Elizium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: But in what habit will you goe along?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Not like a woman, for I would preuent
The loose encounters of lasciuious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with ſuch weedes
As may beseeme ſome well reputed Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then your Ladiship must cut your haire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: No girle, Ile knit it vp in ſilken ſtrings,
With twentie od-conceited true-loue knots:
To be fantastique, may become a youth
Of greater time then I ſhall ſhew to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: What fashion (Madam) ſhall I make your breeches?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: That fits as well, as tell me (good my Lord)
What compaſſe will you weare your Farthingale?
Why eu'n what fashion thou best likes (Lucetta.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: You must needs haue the[m] with a cod-peece Ma-[dam].

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Out, out, (Lucetta) that wilbe illfauourd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: A round hose (Madam) now's not worth a pin
Vnleſſe you haue a cod-peece to ſtick pins on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucetta, as thou lou'st me let me haue
What thou think'st meet, and is mo’t mannerly.
But tell me (wench) how will the world repute me
For vndertaking ſo vnstaid a iourney?
I feare me it will make me ſcandaliz’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: If you thinke ſo, then ſtay at home, and go not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, that I will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Then neuer dreame on Infamy, but go:
If Protheus like your iourney, when you come,
No matter who's displeas’d, when you are gone:
I feare me he will ſcarce be pleas’d with all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: That is the least (Lucetta) of my feare:
A thousand oathes, an Ocean of his teares,
And instances of infinite of Loue,
Warrant me welcome to my Protheus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: All these are ſeruants to deceitfull men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Base men, that vse them to ſo base effect;
But truer ſtarres did gouerne Protheus birth,
His words are bonds, his oathes are oracles,
His loue ſincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His teares, pure meſſengers, ſent from his heart,
His heart, as far from fraud, as heauen from earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray heau'n he proue ſo when you come to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, as thou lou'st me, do him not that wrong,
To beare a hard opinion of his truth:
Onely deserue my loue, by louing him,
And presently goe with me to my chamber
To take a note of what I ſtand in need of,
To furnish me vpon my longing iourney:
All that is mine I leaue at thy dispose,
My goods, my Lands, my reputation,
Onely, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence:
Come; answere not: but to it presently,
I am impatient of my tarriance.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Duke, Thurio, Protheus, Valentine, Launce, Speed

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Thurio, giue vs leaue (I pray) a while,
We haue ſome ſecrets to confer about.
Now tell me Protheus, what’s your will with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious Lord, that which I wold discouer,
The Law of friendship bids me to conceale,
But when I call to minde your gracious fauours
Done to me (vndeseruing as I am)
My dutie pricks me on to vtter that
Which else, no worldly good ſhould draw from me:
Know (worthy Prince) Sir Valentine my friend
This night intends to ſteale away your daughter:
My ſelfe am one made priuy to the plot.
I know you haue determin’d to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates,
And ſhould ſhe thus be ſtolne away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus (for my duties ſake) I rather chose
To croſſe my friend in his intended drift,
Then (by concealing it) heap on your head
A pack of ſorrowes, which would preſſe you downe
(Being vnpreuented) to your timeleſſe graue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Protheus, I thank thee for thine honeſt care,
Which to requite, command me while I liue.
This loue of theirs, my ſelfe haue often ſeene,
Haply when they haue iudg’d me fast asleepe,
And oftentimes haue purpos’d to forbid
Sir Valentine her companie, and my Court.
But fearing lest my iealous ayme might erre,
And ſo (vnworthily) disgrace the man
(A rashneſſe that I euer yet haue ſhun’d)
I gaue him gentle lookes, thereby to finde
That which thy ſelfe hast now disclos’d to me.
And that thou maist perceiue my feare of this,
Knowing that tender youth is ſoone ſuggested,
I nightly lodge her in an vpper Towre,
The key whereof, my ſelfe haue euer kept:
And thence ſhe cannot be conuay’d away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Know (noble Lord) they haue deuis’d a meane
How he her chamber-window will ascend,
And with a Corded-ladder fetch her downe:
For which, the youthfull Louer now is gone,
And this way comes he with it presently.
Where (if it please you) you may intercept him.
But (good my Lord) doe it ſo cunningly
That my discouery be not aimed at:
For, loue of you, not hate vnto my friend,
Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine Honor, he ſhall neuer know
That I had any light from thee of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Adiew, my Lord, Sir Valentine is comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentine, whether away ſo fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Please it your Grace, there is a Meſſenger
That ſtayes to beare my Letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliuer them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Be they of much import?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: The tenure of them doth but ſignifie
My health, and happy being at your Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then no matter: ſtay with me a while,
I am to breake with thee of ſome affaires
That touch me neere: wherein thou must be ſecret.
‘Tis not vnknown to thee, that I haue ſought
To match my friend Sir Thurio, to my daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well (my Lord) and ſure the Match
Were rich and honourable: besides, the gentleman
Is full of Vertue, Bounty, Worth, and Qualities
Beseeming ſuch a Wife, as your faire daughter:
Cannot your Grace win her to fancie him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: No, trust me, She is peeuish, ſullen, froward,
Prowd, disobedient, ſtubborne, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that ſhe is my childe,
Nor fearing me, as if I were her father:
And may I ſay to thee, this pride of hers
(Vpon aduice) hath drawne my loue from her,
And where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should haue beene cherish’d by her child-like dutie,
I now am full resolu’d to take a wife,
And turne her out, to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding dowre:
For me, and my poſſeſſions ſhe esteemes not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: What would your Grace haue me to do in this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a Lady in Verona heere
Whom I affect: but ſhe is nice, and coy,
And naught esteemes my aged eloquence.
Now therefore would I haue thee to my Tutor
(For long agone I haue forgot to court,
Besides the fashion of the time is chang’d)
How, and which way I may bestow my ſelfe
To be regarded in her ſun-bright eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Win her with gifts, if ſhe respect not words,
Dumbe Iewels often in their ſilent kinde
More then quicke words, doe moue a womans minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhe did ſcorne a present that I ſent her,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: A woman ſomtime ſcorns what best co[n]tents her.
Send her another: neuer giue her ore,
For ſcorne at first, makes after-loue the more.
If ſhe doe frowne, ‘tis not in hate of you,
But rather to beget more loue in you.
If ſhe doe chide, ‘tis not to haue you gone,
For why, the fooles are mad, if left alone.
Take no repulse, what euer ſhe doth ſay,
For, get you gon, ſhe doth not meane away.
Flatter, and praise, commend, extoll their graces:
Though nere ſo blacke, ſay they haue Angells faces,
That man that hath a tongue, I ſay is no man,
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhe I meane, is promis’d by her friends
Vnto a youthfull Gentleman of worth,
And kept ſeuerely from resort of men,
That no man hath acceſſe by day to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then I would resort to her by night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but the doores be lockt, and keyes kept ſafe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: What letts but one may enter at her window?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built ſo ſheluing, that one cannot climbe it
Without apparant hazard of his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then a Ladder quaintly made of Cords
To cast vp, with a paire of anchoring hookes,
Would ſerue to ſcale another Hero's towre,
So bold Leander would aduenture it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Now as thou art a Gentleman of blood
Aduise me, where I may haue ſuch a Ladder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: When would you vse it? pray ſir, tell me that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: This very night; for Loue is like a childe
That longs for euery thing that he can come by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: By ſeauen a clock, ile get you ſuch a Ladder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk
SPEECH.LINE: But harke thee: I will goe to her alone,
How ſhall I best conuey the Ladder thither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: It will be light (my Lord) that you may beare it
Vnder a cloake, that is of any length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: A cloake as long as thine will ſerue the turne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let me ſee thy cloake,
Ile get me one of ſuch another length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why any cloake will ſerue the turn (my Lord)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhall I fashion me to weare a cloake?
I pray thee let me feele thy cloake vpon me.
What Letter is this ſame? what’s here? to Siluia?
And heere an Engine fit for my proceeding,
Ile be ſo bold to breake the ſeale for once.
My thoughts do harbour with my Siluia nightly,
And ſlaues they are to me, that ſend them flying.
Oh, could their Master come, and goe as lightly,
Himselfe would lodge where (senceles) they are lying.
My Herald Thoughts, in thy pure bosome rest-them,
While I (their King) that thither them importune
Doe curse the grace, that with ſuch grace hath blest them,
Because my ſelfe doe want my ſeruants fortune.
I curse my ſelfe, for they are ſent by me,
That they ſhould harbour where their Lord ſhould be.
What's here? Siluia, this night I will enfranchise thee.
‘Tis ſo: and heere's the Ladder for the purpose.
Why Phaeton (for thou art Merops ſonne)
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heauenly Car?
And with thy daring folly burne the world?
Wilt thou reach ſtars, because they ſhine on thee?
Goe base Intruder, ouer-weening Slaue,
Bestow thy fawning ſmiles on equall mates,
And thinke my patience, (more then thy desert)
Is priuiledge for thy departure hence.
Thanke me for this, more then for all the fauors
Which (all too-much) I haue bestowed on thee.
But if thou linger in my Territories
Longer then ſwiftest expedition
Will giue thee time to leaue our royall Court,
By heauen, my wrath ſhall farre exceed the loue
I euer bore my daughter, or thy ſelfe.
Be gone, I will not heare thy vaine excuse,
But as thou lou'st thy life, make ſpeed from hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: And why not death, rather then liuing torment?
To die, is to be banisht from my ſelfe,
And Siluia is my ſelfe: banish’d from her
Is ſelfe from ſelfe. A deadly banishment:
What light, is light, if Siluia be not ſeene?
What ioy is ioy, if Siluia be not by?
Vnleſſe it be to thinke that ſhe is by
And feed vpon the ſhadow of perfection.
Except I be by Siluia in the night,
There is no musicke in the Nightingale.
Vnleſſe I looke on Siluia in the day,
There is no day for me to looke vpon.
Shee is my eſſence, and I leaue to be;
If I be not by her faire influence
Foster’d, illumin’d, cherish’d, kept aliue.
I flie not death, to flie his deadly doome,
Tarry I heere, I but attend on death,
But flie I hence, I flie away from life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Run (boy) run, run, and ſeeke him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: So-hough, Soa hough—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſeest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Him we goe to finde,
There's not a haire on's head, but ‘tis a Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Valentine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Who then? his Spirit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Can nothing ſpeake? Master, ſhall I ſtrike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Who wouldst thou ſtrike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine, forbeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Sir, Ile ſtrike nothing: I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirha, I ſay forbeare: friend Valentine, a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: My eares are ſtopt, & cannot hear good newes,
So much of bad already hath poſſest them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Then in dumbe ſilence will I bury mine,
For they are harsh, vn-tuneable, and bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Siluia dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No Valentine indeed, for ſacred Siluia,
Hath ſhe forsworne me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No Valentine, if Siluia haue forsworne me.
What is your newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, there is a proclamation, y you are vanished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: That thou art banish’d: oh that’s the newes,
From hence, from Siluia, and from me thy friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I haue fed vpon this wœ already,
And now exceſſe of it will make me ſurfet.
Doth Siluia know that I am banish’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I: and ſhe hath offered to the doome
(Which vn-reuerst ſtands in effectuall force)
A Sea of melting pearle, which ſome call teares;
Those at her fathers churlish feete ſhe tenderd,
With them vpon her knees, her humble ſelfe,
Wringing her hands, whose whitenes ſo became them,
As if but now they waxed pale for wœ:
But neither bended knees, pure hands held vp,
Sad ſighes, deepe grones, nor ſiluer-shedding teares
Could penetrate her vncompaſſionate Sire;
But Valentine, if he be tane, must die.
Besides, her interceſſion chaf’d him ſo,
When ſhe for thy repeale was ſuppliant,
That to close prison he commanded her,
With many bitter threats of biding there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: No more: vnles the next word that thou ſpeak'st
Haue ſome malignant power vpon my life:
If ſo: I pray thee breath it in mine eare,
As ending Antheme of my endleſſe dolor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Cease to lament for that thou canst not helpe,
And ſtudy helpe for that which thou lament'st,
Time is the Nurse, and breeder of all good;
Here, if thou ſtay, thou canst not ſee thy loue:
Besides, thy ſtaying will abridge thy life:
Hope is a louers ſtaffe, walke hence with that
And manage it, against despairing thoughts:
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence,
Which, being writ to me, ſhall be deliuer’d
Euen in the milke-white bosome of thy Loue.
The time now ſerues not to expostulate,
Come, Ile conuey thee through the City-gate.
And ere I part with thee, confer at large
Of all that may concerne thy Loue-affaires:
As thou lou'st Siluia (though not for thy ſelfe)
Regard thy danger, and along with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee Launce, and if thou ſeest my Boy
Bid him make haste, and meet me at the North-gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe ſirha, finde him out: Come Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my deere Siluia; hapleſſe Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Launce.
SPEECH.LINE: I am but a foole, looke you, and yet I haue the wit to thinke my Master is a kinde of a knaue: but that’s all one, if he be but one knaue: He liues not now that knowes me to be in loue, yet I am in loue, but a Teeme of horse ſhall not plucke that from me: nor who ‘tis I loue: and yet ‘tis a woman; but what woman, I will not tell my ſelfe: and yet ‘tis a Milke-maid: yet ‘tis not a maid: for ſhee hath had Goſſips: yet ‘tis a maid, for ſhe is her Masters maid, and ſerues for wages. Shee hath more qualities then a Water-Spaniell, which is much in a bare Christian: Heere is the Cate-log of her Condition. Inprimis. Shee can fetch and carry: why a horse can doe no more; nay, a horse cannot fetch, but onely carry, therefore is ſhee better then a Iade. Item. She can milke, looke you, a ſweet vertue in a maid with cleane hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Speed.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Signior Launce? what newes with your Mastership?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: With my Mastership? why, it is at Sea:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, your old vice ſtill: mistake the word: what newes then in your paper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: The black'st newes that euer thou heard'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Why man? how blacke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, as blacke as Inke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me read them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie on thee Iolt-head, thou canst not read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lyest: I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I will try thee: tell me this: who begot thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, the ſon of my Grand-father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh illiterate loyterer; it was the ſonne of thy
Grand-mother: this proues that thou canst not read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Come foole, come: try me in thy paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: There: and S[aint]. Nicholas be thy ſpeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Inprimis ſhe can milke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I that ſhe can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe brewes good Ale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: And thereof comes the prouerbe: (Bleſſing of your heart, you brew good Ale.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe can ſowe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to ſay (Can ſhe ſo?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item ſhe can knit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: What neede a man care for a ſtock with a wench,
When ſhe can knit him a ſtocke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe can wash and ſcoure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſpeciall vertue: for then ſhee neede not be wash’d, and ſcowr’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe can ſpin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Then may I ſet the world on wheeles, when ſhe can ſpin for her liuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe hath many nameleſſe vertues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: That's as much as to ſay Bastard-vertues: that indeede know not their fathers; and therefore haue no names.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Here follow her vices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Close at the heeles of her vertues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhee is not to be fasting in respect of her breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: that fault may be mended with a break-fast: read on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe hath a ſweet mouth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: That makes amends for her ſoure breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe doth talke in her ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: It's no matter for that; ſo ſhee ſleepe not in her talke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe is ſlow in words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh villaine, that ſet this downe among her vices;
To be ſlow in words, is a womans onely vertue:
I pray thee out with't, and place it for her chiefe vertue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe is proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Out with that too:
It was Eues legacie, and cannot be t'ane from her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe hath no teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I care not for that neither: because I loue crusts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe is curst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: the best is, ſhe hath no teeth to bite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe will often praise her liquor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: If her liquor be good, ſhe ſhall: if ſhe will not,
I will; for good things ſhould be praised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe is too liberall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Of her tongue ſhe cannot; for that’s writ downe ſhe is ſlow of: of her purse, ſhee ſhall not, for that ile keepe ſhut: Now, of another thing ſhee may, and that cannot I helpe. Well, proceede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhee hath more haire then wit, and more faults then haires, and more wealth then faults.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Stop there: Ile haue her: ſhe was mine, and not mine, twice or thrice in that last Article: rehearse that once more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Item, ſhe hath more haire then wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: More haire then wit: it may be ile proue it: The couer of the ſalt, hides the ſalt, and therefore it is more then the ſalt; the haire that couers the wit, is more then the wit; for the greater hides the leſſe: What's next?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: And more faults then haires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: That's monstrous: oh that that were out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: And more wealth then faults.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that word makes the faults gracious: Well, ile haue her: and if it be a match, as nothing is impoſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: What then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then, will I tell thee, that thy Master ſtaies for thee at the North gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: For me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: For thee? I, who art thou? he hath ſtaid for a bet-ter man then thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: And must I goe to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou must run to him; for thou hast ſtaid ſo long, that going will ſcarce ſerue the turne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Why didst not tell me ſooner? 'pox of your loue
Letters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Now will he be ſwing’d for reading my Letter;
An vnmannerly ſlaue, that will thrust himselfe into ſe-crets:
Ile after, to reioyce in the boyes correctio[n].

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Thurio, feare not, but that ſhe will loue you
Now Valentine is banish’d from her ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: Since his exile ſhe hath despis’d me mo’t,
Forsworne my company, and rail’d at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: This weake impreſſe of Loue, is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an houres heate
Diſſolues to water, and doth loose his forme.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts,
And worthleſſe Valentine ſhall be forgot.
How now ſir Protheus, is your countriman
(According to our Proclamation) gon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Gon, my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: My daughter takes his going grieuously?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: A little time (my Lord) will kill that griefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: So I beleeue: but Thurio thinkes not ſo:
Protheus, the good conceit I hold of thee,
(For thou hast ſhowne ſome ſigne of good desert)
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Longer then I proue loyall to your Grace,
Let me not liue, to looke vpon your Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou know'st how willingly, I would effect
The match betweene ſir Thurio, and my daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: And also, I thinke, thou art not ignorant
How ſhe opposes her against my will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: She did my Lord, when Valentine was here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and peruersly, ſhe perseuers ſo:
What might we doe to make the girle forget
The loue of Valentine, and loue ſir Thurio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: The best way is, to ſlander Valentine,
With falsehood, cowardize, and poore discent:
Three things, that women highly hold in hate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but ſhe'll thinke, that it is ſpoke in hate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if his enemy deliuer it.
Therefore it must with circumstance be ſpoken
By one, whom ſhe esteemeth as his friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Then you must vndertake to ſlander him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And that (my Lord) I ſhall be loath to doe:
‘Tis an ill office for a Gentleman,
Especially against his very friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Where your good word cannot aduantage him,
Your ſlander neuer can endamage him;
Therefore the office is indifferent,
Being intreated to it by your friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue preuail’d (my Lord) if I can doe it
By ought that I can ſpeake in his dispraise,
She ſhall not long continue loue to him:
But ſay this weede her loue from Valentine,
It followes not that ſhe will loue ſir Thurio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore, as you vnwinde her loue from him;
Least it ſhould rauell, and be good to none,
You must prouide to bottome it on me:
Which must be done, by praising me as much
As you, in worth dispraise, ſir Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: And Protheus, we dare trust you in this kinde,
Because we know (on Valentines report)
You are already loues firme votary,
And cannot ſoone reuolt, and change your minde.
Vpon this warrant, ſhall you haue acceſſe,
