Where you, with Siluia, may conferre at large.
For ſhe is lumpish, heauy, mellancholly,
And (for your friends ſake) will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her, by your perswasion,
To hate yong Valentine, and loue my friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: As much as I can doe, I will effect:
But you ſir Thurio, are not ſharpe enough:
You must lay Lime, to tangle her desires
By walefull Sonnets, whose composed Rimes
Should be full fraught with ſeruiceable vowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: I, much is the force of heauen-bred Pœsie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Say that vpon the altar of her beauty
You ſacrifice your teares, your ſighes, your heart:
Write till your inke be dry: and with your teares
Moist it againe: and frame ſome feeling line,
That may discouer ſuch integrity:
For Orpheus Lute, was ſtrung with Pœts ſinewes,
Whose golden touch could ſoften ſteele and ſtones;
Make Tygers tame, and huge Leuiathans
Forsake vnsounded deepes, to dance on Sands.
After your dire-lamenting Elegies,
Visit by night your Ladies chamber-window
With ſome ſweet Consort; To their Instruments
Tune a deploring dumpe: the nights dead ſilence
Will well become ſuch ſweet complaining grieuance:
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: This discipline, ſhowes thou hast bin in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: And thy aduice, this night, ile put in practise:
Therefore, ſweet Protheus, my direction-giuer,
Let vs into the City presently
To ſort ſome Gentlemen, well ſkil’d in Musicke.
I haue a Sonnet, that will ſerue the turne
To giue the on-set to thy good aduise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: About it Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: We'll wait vpon your Grace, till after Supper,
And afterward determine our proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du
SPEECH.LINE: Euen now about it, I will pardon you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Valentine, Speed, and certaine Out-lawes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out-l.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellowes, ſtand fast: I ſee a paſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be ten, ſhrinke not, but down with 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand ſir, and throw vs that you haue about 'ye.
If not: we'll make you ſit, and rifle you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir we are vndone; these are the Villaines
That all the Trauailers doe feare ſo much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: My friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: That's not ſo, ſir: we are your enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace: we'll heare him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: I by my beard will we: for he is a proper man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Then know that I haue little wealth to loose;
A man I am, croſſ’d with aduersitie:
My riches, are these poore habiliments,
Of which, if you ſhould here disfurnish me,
You take the ſum and ſubstance that I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether trauell you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: To Verona.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Whence came you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: From Millaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you long ſoiourn’d there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Some ſixteene moneths, and longer might haue ſtaid,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: What, were you banish’d thence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: For what offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: For that which now torments me to rehearse;
I kil’d a man, whose death I much repent,
But yet I ſlew him manfully, in fight,
Without false vantage, or base treachery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Why nere repent it, if it were done ſo;
But were you banisht for ſo ſmall a fault?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I was, and held me glad of ſuch a doome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you the Tongues?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: My youthfull trauaile, therein made me happy,
Or else I often had beene often miserable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: By the bare ſcalpe of Robin Hoods fat Fryer,
This fellow were a King, for our wilde faction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: We'll haue him: Sirs, a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sp.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, be one of them:
It's an honourable kinde of theeuery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell vs this: haue you any thing to take to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but my fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Know then, that ſome of vs are Gentlemen,
Such as the fury of vngouern’d youth
Thrust from the company of awfull men.
My ſelfe was from Verona banished,
For practising to ſteale away a Lady,
And heire and Neece, alide vnto the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: And I from Mantua, for a Gentleman,
Who, in my moode, I ſtab’d vnto the heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: And I, for ſuch like petty crimes as these.
But to the purpose: for we cite our faults,
That they may hold excus’d our lawleſſe liues;
And partly ſeeing you are beautifide
With goodly ſhape; and by your owne report,
A Linguist, and a man of ſuch perfection,
As we doe in our quality much want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeede because you are a banish’d man,
Therefore, aboue the rest, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our Generall?
To make a vertue of neceſſity,
And liue as we doe in this wilderneſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaist thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say I, and be the captaine of vs all:
We'll doe thee homage, and be rul’d by thee,
Loue thee, as our Commander, and our King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: But if thou ſcorne our curtesie, thou dyest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt not liue, to brag what we haue offer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I take your offer, and will liue with you,
Prouided that you do no outrages
On ſilly women, or poore paſſengers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: No, we detest ſuch vile base practises.
Come, goe with vs, we'll bring thee to our Crewes,
And ſhow thee all the Treasure we haue got;
Which, with our ſelues, all rest at thy dispose.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Protheus, Thurio, Iulia, Host, Musitian, Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Already haue I bin false to Valentine,
And now I must be as vniust to Thurio,
Vnder the colour of commending him,
I haue acceſſe my owne loue to prefer.
But Siluia is too faire, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthleſſe guifts;
When I protest true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vowes,
She bids me thinke how I haue bin forsworne
In breaking faith with Iulia, whom I lou’d;
And notwithstanding all her ſodaine quips,
The least whereof would quell a louers hope:
Yet (Spaniel-like) the more ſhe ſpurnes my loue,
The more it growes, and fawneth on her ſtill;
But here comes Thurio; now must we to her window,
And giue ſome euening Musique to her eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, ſir Protheus, are you crept before vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I gentle Thurio, for you know that loue
Will creepe in ſeruice, where it cannot goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but I hope, Sir, that you loue not here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, but I doe: or else I would be hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, Siluia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Siluia, for your ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you for your owne: Now Gentlemen
Let's tune: and too it lustily a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, my yong guest; me thinks your' allycholly;
I pray you why is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry (mine Host) because I cannot be merry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, we'll haue you merry: ile bring you where you ſhall heare Musique, and ſee the Gentleman that you ask’d for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhall I heare him ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: I that you ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: That will be Musique.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Harke, harke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he among these?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: I: but peace, let's heare'm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Song.
SPEECH.LINE: Who is Siluia? what is ſhe? That all our Swaines commend her? Holy, faire, and wise is ſhe, The heauen ſuch grace did lend her, that ſhe might admired be. Is ſhe kinde as ſhe is faire? For beauty liues with kindneſſe: Loue doth to her eyes repaire, To helpe him of his blindneſſe: And being help’d, inhabits there. Then to Siluia, let vs ſing, That Siluia is excelling; She excels each mortall thing Vpon the dull earth dwelling. To her let vs Garlands bring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? are you ſadder then you were before;
How doe you, man? the Musicke likes you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: You mistake: the Musitian likes me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, my pretty youth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: He plaies false (father.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: How, out of tune on the ſtrings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo: but yet
So false that he grieues my very heart-strings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue a quicke eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I would I were deafe: it makes me haue a ſlow heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: I perceiue you delight not in Musique.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a whit, when it iars ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Harke, what fine change is in the Musique.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: I: that change is the ſpight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: You would haue them alwaies play but one thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: I would alwaies haue one play but one thing.
But Host, doth this Sir Protheus, that we talke on,
Often resort vnto this Gentlewoman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell you what Launce his man told me,
He lou’d her out of all nicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Launce?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Gone to ſeeke his dog, which to morrow, by his
Masters command, hee must carry for a present to his
Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, ſtand aside, the company parts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Thurio, feare not you, I will ſo pleade,
That you ſhall ſay, my cunning drift excels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: Where meete we?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: At Saint Gregories well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam: good eu'n to your Ladiship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you for your Musique (Gentlemen)
Who is that that ſpake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: One (Lady) if you knew his pure hearts truth,
You would quickly learne to know him by his voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Protheus, as I take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Protheus (gentle Lady) and your Seruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: That I may compaſſe yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue your wish: my will is euen this,
That presently you hie you home to bed:
Thou ſubtile, periur’d, false, disloyall man:
Think'st thou I am ſo ſhallow, ſo conceitleſſe,
To be ſeduced by thy flattery,
That has't deceiu’d ſo many with thy vowes?
Returne, returne, and make thy loue amends:
For me (by this pale queene of night I ſweare)
I am ſo farre from granting thy request,
That I despise thee, for thy wrongfull ſuite;
And by and by intend to chide my ſelfe,
Euen for this time I ſpend in talking to thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I grant (sweet loue) that I did loue a Lady,
But ſhe is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere false, if I ſhould ſpeake it;
For I am ſure ſhe is not buried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Say that ſhe be: yet Valentine thy friend
Suruiues; to whom (thy ſelfe art witneſſe)
I am betroth’d; and art thou not asham’d
To wrong him, with thy importunacy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I likewise heare that Valentine is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo ſuppose am I; for in her graue
Aſſure thy ſelfe, my loue is buried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Lady, let me rake it from the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe to thy Ladies graue and call hers thence,
Or at the least, in hers, ſepulcher thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: He heard not that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam: if your heart be ſo obdurate:
Vouchsafe me yet your Picture for my loue,
The Picture that is hanging in your chamber:
To that ile ſpeake, to that ile ſigh and weepe:
For ſince the ſubstance of your perfect ſelfe
Is else deuoted, I am but a ſhadow;
And to your ſhadow, will I make true loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: If 'twere a ſubstance you would ſure deceiue it,
And make it but a ſhadow, as I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: I am very loath to be your Idoll Sir;
But, ſince your falsehood ſhall become you well
To worship ſhadowes, and adore false ſhapes,
Send to me in the morning, and ile ſend it:
And ſo, good rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: As wretches haue ore-night
That wait for execution in the morne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Host, will you goe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: By my hallidome, I was fast asleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you, where lies Sir Protheus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, at my house:
Trust me, I thinke ‘tis almost day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo: but it hath bin the longest night
That ere I watch’d, and the mo’t heauiest.
Scœna Tertia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eg.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the houre that Madam Siluia
Entreated me to call, and know her minde:
Ther's ſome great matter ſhe'ld employ me in.
Madam, Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Who cals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eg.
SPEECH.LINE: Your ſeruant, and your friend;
One that attends your Ladiships command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Eglamore, a thousand times good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eg.
SPEECH.LINE: As many (worthy Lady) to your ſelfe:
According to your Ladiships impose,
I am thus early come, to know what ſeruice
It is your pleasure to command me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Eglamoure, thou art a Gentleman:
Thinke not I flatter (for I ſweare I doe not)
Valiant, wise, remorse-full, well accomplish’d.
Thou art not ignorant what deere good will
I beare vnto the banish’d Valentine:
Nor how my father would enforce me marry
Vaine Thurio (whom my very ſoule abhor’d.)
Thy ſelfe hast lou’d, and I haue heard thee ſay
No griefe did euer come ſo neere thy heart,
As when thy Lady, and thy true-loue dide,
Vpon whose Graue thou vow’dst pure chastitie:
Sir Eglamoure: I would to Valentine
To Mantua, where I heare, he makes aboad;
And for the waies are dangerous to paſſe,
I doe desire thy worthy company,
Vpon whose faith and honor, I repose.
Vrge not my fathers anger (Eglamoure)
But thinke vpon my griefe (a Ladies griefe)
And on the iustice of my flying hence,
To keepe me from a mo’t vnholy match,
Which heauen and fortune ſtill rewards with plagues.
I doe desire thee, euen from a heart
As full of ſorrowes, as the Sea of ſands,
To beare me company, and goe with me:
If not, to hide what I haue ſaid to thee,
That I may venture to depart alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Egl.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I pitty much your grieuances,
Which, ſince I know they vertuously are plac’d,
I giue consent to goe along with you,
Wreaking as little what betideth me,
As much, I wish all good befortune you.
When will you goe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: This euening comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eg.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſhall I meete you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: At Frier Patrickes Cell,
Where I intend holy Confeſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eg.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not faile your Ladiship:
Good morrow (gentle Lady.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow, kinde Sir Eglamoure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lau.
SPEECH.LINE: When a mans ſeruant ſhall play the Curre with him (looke you) it goes hard: one that I brought vp of a puppy: one that I ſau’d from drowning, when three or foure of his blinde brothers and ſisters went to it: I haue taught him (euen as one would ſay precisely, thus I would teach a dog) I was ſent to deliuer him, as a pre-sent to Mistris Siluia, from my Master; and I came no ſooner into the dyning-chamber, but he ſteps me to her Trencher, and ſteales her Capons-leg: O, ‘tis a foule thing, when a Cur cannot keepe himselfe in all compa-nies: I would haue (as one ſhould ſay) one that takes vp-on him to be a dog indeede, to be, as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had more wit then he, to take a fault vpon me that he did, I thinke verily hee had bin hang’d for't: ſure as I liue he had ſuffer’d for't: you ſhall iudge: Hee thrusts me himselfe into the company of three or foure gentleman-like-dogs, vnder the Dukes table: hee had not bin there (bleſſe the marke) a piſſing while, but all the chamber ſmelt him: out with the dog (ſaies one) what cur is that (ſaies another) whip him out (ſaies the third) hang him vp (ſaies the Duke.) I hauing bin ac-quainted with the ſmell before, knew it was Crab; and goes me to the fellow that whips the dogges: friend (quoth I) you meane to whip the dog: I marry doe I (quoth he) you doe him the more wrong (quoth I) 'twas I did the thing you wot of: he makes me no more adœ, but whips me out of the chamber: how many Masters would doe this for his Seruant? nay, ile be ſworne I haue ſat in the ſtockes, for puddings he hath ſtolne, otherwise he had bin executed: I haue ſtood on the Pillorie for Geese he hath kil’d, otherwise he had ſufferd for't: thou think'st not of this now: nay, I remember the tricke you ſeru’d me, when I tooke my leaue of Madam Siluia: did not I bid thee ſtill marke me, and doe as I do; when did'st thou ſee me heaue vp my leg, and make water against a Gentlewomans farthingale? did'st thou euer ſee me doe ſuch a tricke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sebastian is thy name: I like thee well,
And will imploy thee in ſome ſeruice presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iu.
SPEECH.LINE: In what you please, ile doe what I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope thou wilt.
How now you whor-son pezant,
Where haue you bin these two dayes loytering?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, I carried Mistris Siluia the dogge you bad me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And what ſaies ſhe to my little Iewell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſhe ſaies your dog was a cur, and tels you currish thanks is good enough for ſuch a present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhe receiu’d my dog?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: No indeede did ſhe not:
Here haue I brought him backe againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir, the other Squirrill was ſtolne from me
By the Hangmans boyes in the market place,
And then I offer’d her mine owne, who is a dog
As big as ten of yours, & therefore the guift the greater.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe, get thee hence, and finde my dog againe,
Or nere returne againe into my ſight.
Away, I ſay: ſtayest thou to vexe me here;
A Slaue, that ſtill an end, turnes me to ſhame:
Sebastian, I haue entertained thee,
Partly that I haue neede of ſuch a youth,
That can with ſome discretion doe my busineſſe:
For ‘tis no trusting to yond foolish Lowt;
But chiefely, for thy face, and thy behauiour,
Which (if my Augury deceiue me not)
Witneſſe good bringing vp, fortune, and truth:
Therefore know thee, for this I entertaine thee.
Go presently, and take this Ring with thee,
Deliuer it to Madam Siluia;
She lou’d me well, deliuer’d it to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſeemes you lou’d not her, not leaue her token:
She is dead belike?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo: I thinke ſhe liues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do'st thou cry alas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot choose but pitty her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore ſhould'st thou pitty her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Because, me thinkes that ſhe lou’d you as well
As you doe loue your Lady Siluia:
She dreames on him, that has forgot her loue,
You doate on her, that cares not for your loue.
‘Tis pitty Loue, ſhould be ſo contrary:
And thinking on it, makes me cry alas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: giue her that Ring, and therewithall
This Letter: that’s her chamber: Tell my Lady,
I claime the promise for her heauenly Picture:
Your meſſage done, hye home vnto my chamber,
Where thou ſhalt finde me ſad, and ſolitarie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: How many women would doe ſuch a meſſage?
Alas poore Protheus, thou hast entertain’d
A Foxe, to be the Shepheard of thy Lambs;
Alas, poore foole, why doe I pitty him
That with his very heart despiseth me?
Because he loues her, he despiseth me,
Because I loue him, I must pitty him.
This Ring I gaue him, when he parted from me,
To binde him to remember my good will:
And now am I (vnhappy Meſſenger)
To plead for that, which I would not obtaine;
To carry that, which I would haue refus’d;
To praise his faith, which I would haue disprais’d.
I am my Masters true confirmed Loue,
But cannot be true ſeruant to my Master,
Vnleſſe I proue false traitor to my ſelfe.
Yet will I wœ for him, but yet ſo coldly,
As (heauen it knowes) I would not haue him ſpeed.
Gentlewoman, good day: I pray you be my meane
To bring me where to ſpeake with Madam Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you with her, if that I be ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: If you be ſhe, I doe intreat your patience
To heare me ſpeake the meſſage I am ſent on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: From whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: From my Master, Sir Protheus, Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh: he ſends you for a Picture?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Vrsula, bring my Picture there,
Goe, giue your Master this: tell him from me,
One Iulia, that his changing thoughts forget
Would better fit his Chamber, then this Shadow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, please you peruse this Letter;
Pardon me (Madam) I haue vnaduis’d
Deliuer’d you a paper that I ſhould not;
This is the Letter to your Ladiship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee let me looke on that againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: It may not be: good Madam pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: There, hold:
I will not looke vpon your Masters lines:
I know they are ſtuft with protestations,
And full of new-found oathes, which he will breake
As easily, as I doe teare his paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, he ſends your Ladiship this Ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: The more ſhame for him, that he ſends it me;
For I haue heard him ſay a thousand times,
His Iulia gaue it him, at his departure:
Though his false finger haue prophan’d the Ring,
Mine ſhall not doe his Iulia ſo much wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: She thankes you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſai'st thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you Madam, that you tender her:
Poore Gentlewoman, my Master wrongs her much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou know her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Almost as well as I doe know my ſelfe.
To thinke vpon her wœs, I doe protest
That I haue wept a hundred ſeuerall times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Belike ſhe thinks that Protheus hath forsook her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſhe doth: and that’s her cause of ſorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe not paſſing faire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: She hath bin fairer (Madam) then ſhe is,
When ſhe did thinke my Master lou’d her well;
She, in my iudgement, was as faire as you.
But ſince ſhe did neglect her looking-glaſſe,
And threw her Sun-expelling Masque away,
The ayre hath ſtaru’d the roses in her cheekes,
And pinch’d the lilly-tincture of her face,
That now ſhe is become as blacke as I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: How tall was ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: About my ſtature: for at Pentecost,
When all our Pageants of delight were plaid,
Our youth got me to play the womans part,
And I was trim’d in Madam Iulias gowne,
Which ſerued me as fit, by all mens iudgements,
As if the garment had bin made for me:
Therefore I know ſhe is about my height,
And at that time I made her weepe a good,
For I did play a lamentable part.
(Madam) 'twas Ariadne, paſſioning
For Thesus periury, and vniust flight;
Which I ſo liuely acted with my teares:
That my poore Mistris moued therewithall,
Wept bitterly: and would I might be dead,
If I in thought felt not her very ſorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: She is beholding to thee (gentle youth)
Alas (poore Lady) desolate, and left;
I weepe my ſelfe to thinke vpon thy words:
Here youth: there is my purse; I giue thee this
For thy ſweet Mistris ſake, because thou lou'st her. Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhe ſhall thanke you for't, if ere you know her.
A vertuous gentlewoman, milde, and beautifull.
I hope my Masters ſuit will be but cold,
Since ſhe respects my Mistris loue ſo much.
Alas, how loue can trifle with it ſelfe:
Here is her Picture: let me ſee, I thinke
If I had ſuch a Tyre, this face of mine
Were full as louely, as is this of hers;
And yet the Painter flatter’d her a little,
Vnleſſe I flatter with my ſelfe too much.
Her haire is Aburne, mine is perfect Yellow;
If that be all the difference in his loue,
Ile get me ſuch a coulour’d Perrywig:
Her eyes are grey as glaſſe, and ſo are mine.
I, but her fore-head's low, and mine's as high:
What ſhould it be that he respects in her,
But I can make respectiue in my ſelfe?
If this fond Loue, were not a blinded god.
Come ſhadow, come, and take this ſhadow vp,
For ‘tis thy riuall: O thou ſenceleſſe forme,
Thou ſhalt be worship’d, kiſſ’d, lou’d, and ador’d;
And were there ſence in his Idolatry,
My ſubstance ſhould be ſtatue in thy ſtead.
Ile vse thee kindly, for thy Mistris ſake
That vs’d me ſo: or else by Ioue, I vow,
I ſhould haue ſcratch’d out your vnseeing eyes,
To make my Master out of loue with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Egl.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sun begins to guild the westerne ſkie,
And now it is about the very houre
That Siluia, at Fryer Patricks Cell ſhould meet me,
She will not faile; for Louers breake not houres,
Vnleſſe it be to come before their time,
So much they ſpur their expedition.
See where ſhe comes: Lady a happy euening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, Amen: goe on (good Eglamoure)
Out at the Posterne by the Abbey wall;
I feare I am attended by ſome Spies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Egl.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not: the Forrest is not three leagues off,
If we recouer that, we are ſure enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Th.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Protheus, what ſaies Siluia to my ſuit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Sir, I finde her milder then ſhe was,
And yet ſhe takes exceptions at your person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: What? that my leg is too long?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, that it is too little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile weare a Boote, to make it ſomewhat rounder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But loue will not be ſpurd to what it loathes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies ſhe to my face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſaies it is a faire one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then the wanton lyes: my face is blacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But Pearles are faire; and the old ſaying is,
Blacke men are Pearles, in beauteous Ladies eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true, ſuch Pearles as put out Ladies eyes,
For I had rather winke, then looke on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: How likes ſhe my discourse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ill, when you talke of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: But well, when I discourse of loue and peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: But better indeede, when you hold you peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſayes ſhe to my valour?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Sir, ſhe makes no doubt of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: She needes not, when ſhe knowes it cowardize.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies ſhe to my birth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: That you are well deriu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: True: from a Gentleman, to a foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Considers ſhe my Poſſeſſions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I: and pitties them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſuch an Aſſe ſhould owe them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: That they are out by Lease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: How now ſir Protheus; how now Thurio?
Which of you ſaw Eglamoure of late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Saw you my daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then
She's fled vnto that pezant, Valentine;
And Eglamoure is in her Company:
‘Tis true: for Frier Laurence met them both
As he, in pennance wander’d through the Forrest:
Him he knew well: and guesd that it was ſhe,
But being mask’d, he was not ſure of it.
Besides ſhe did intend Confeſſion
At Patricks Cell this euen, and there ſhe was not.
These likelihoods confirme her flight from hence;
Therefore I pray you ſtand, not to discourse,
But mount you presently, and meete with me
Vpon the rising of the Mountaine foote
That leads toward Mantua, whether they are fled:
Dispatch (sweet Gentlemen) and follow me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this it is, to be a peeuish Girle,
That flies her fortune when it followes her:
Ile after; more to be reueng’d on Eglamoure,
Then for the loue of reck-leſſe Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will follow, more for Siluias loue
Then hate of Eglamoure that goes with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will follow, more to croſſe that loue
Then hate for Siluia, that is gone for loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come be patient:
We must bring you to our Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand more mischances then this one
Haue learn’d me how to brooke this patiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, bring her away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the Gentleman that was with her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3 Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Being nimble footed, he hath out-run vs.
But Moyses and Valerius follow him:
Goe thou with her to the West end of the wood,
There is our Captaine: Wee'll follow him that’s fled,
The Thicket is beset, he cannot ſcape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Out.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, I must bring you to our Captains caue.
Feare not: he beares an honourable minde,
And will not vse a woman lawlesly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: O Valentine: this I endure for thee.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Valentine, Protheus, Siluia, Iulia, Duke, Thurio, Out-lawes

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How vse doth breed a habit in a man?
This ſhadowy desart, vnfrequented woods
I better brooke then flourishing peopled Townes:
Here can I ſit alone, vn-seene of any,
And to the Nightingales complaining Notes
Tune my distreſſes, and record my wœs.
O thou that dost inhabit in my brest,
Leaue not the Mansion ſo long Tenant-leſſe,
Lest growing ruinous, the building fall,
And leaue no memory of what it was,
Repaire me, with thy presence, Siluia:
Thou gentle Nimph, cherish thy for-lorne ſwaine.
What hallowing, and what ſtir is this to day?
These are my mates, that make their wills their Law,
Haue ſome vnhappy paſſenger in chace;
They loue me well: yet I haue much to doe
To keepe them from vnciuill outrages.
Withdraw thee Valentine: who's this comes heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, this ſeruice I haue done for you
(Though you respect not aught your ſeruant doth)
To hazard life, and reskew you from him,
That would haue forc’d your honour, and your loue,
Vouchsafe me for my meed, but one faire looke:
(A ſmaller boone then this I cannot beg,
And leſſe then this, I am ſure you cannot giue.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: How like a dreame is this? I ſee, and heare:
Loue, lend me patience to forbeare a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: O miserable, vnhappy that I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnhappy were you (Madam) ere I came:
But by my comming, I haue made you happy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: By thy approach thou mak'st me mo’t vnhappy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And me, when he approcheth to your presence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Had I beene ceazed by a hungry Lion,
I would haue beene a break-fast to the Beast,
Rather then haue false Protheus reskue me:
Oh heauen be iudge how I loue Valentine,
Whose life's as tender to me as my ſoule,
And full as much (for more there cannot be)
I doe detest false periur’d Protheus:
Therefore be gone, ſollicit me no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What dangerous action, ſtood it next to death
Would I not vndergœ, for one calme looke:
Oh ‘tis the curse in Loue, and ſtill approu’d
When women cannot loue, where they're belou’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: When Protheus cannot loue, where he's belou’d:
Read ouer Iulia's heart, (thy first best Loue)
For whose deare ſake, thou didst then rend thy faith
Into a thousand oathes; and all those oathes,
Descended into periury, to loue me,
Thou hast no faith left now, vnleſſe thou’dst two,
And that’s farre worse then none: better haue none
Then plurall faith, which is too much by one:
Thou Counterfeyt, to thy true friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: In Loue,
Who respects friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: All men but Protheus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if the gentle ſpirit of mouing words
Can no way change you to a milder forme;
Ile woœ you like a Souldier, at armes end,
And loue you 'gainst the nature of Loue: force ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sil.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile force thee yeeld to my desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Ruffian: let goe that rude vnciuill touch,
Thou friend of an ill fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou co[m]mon friend, that’s without faith or loue,
For ſuch is a friend now: treacherous man,
Thou hast beguil’d my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could haue perswaded me: now I dare not ſay
I haue one friend aliue; thou wouldst disproue me:
Who ſhould be trusted, when ones right hand
Is periured to the bosome? Protheus
I am ſorry I must neuer trust thee more,
But count the world a ſtranger for thy ſake:
The priuate wound is deepest: oh time, mo’t accurst.
'Mongst all fœs that a friend ſhould be the worst?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My ſhame and guilt confounds me:
Forgiue me Valentine: if hearty ſorrow
Be a ſufficient Ransome for offence,
I tender't heere: I doe as truely ſuffer,
As ere I did commit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I am paid:
And once againe, I doe receiue thee honeſt;
Who by Repentance is not ſatisfied,
Is nor of heauen, nor earth; for these are pleas’d:
By Penitence th’ Eternalls wrath's appeas’d:
And that my loue may appeare plaine and free,
All that was mine, in Siluia, I giue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh me vnhappy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke to the Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Boy?
Why wag: how now? what’s the matter? look vp: ſpeak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: O good ſir, my master charg’d me to deliuer a ring to Madam Siluia: w (out of my neglect) was neuer done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is that ring? boy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ‘tis: this is it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: How? let me ſee.
Why this is the ring I gaue to Iulia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, cry you mercy ſir, I haue mistooke:
This is the ring you ſent to Siluia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But how cam'st thou by this ring? at my depart
I gaue this vnto Iulia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And Iulia her ſelfe did giue it me,
And Iulia her ſelfe hath brought it hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: How? Iulia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold her, that gaue ayme to all thy oathes,
And entertain’d 'em deepely in her heart.
How oft hast thou with periury cleft the roote?
Oh Protheus, let this habit make thee blush.
Be thou asham’d that I haue tooke vpon me,
Such an immodest rayment; if ſhame liue
In a disguise of loue?
It is the leſſer blot modesty findes,
Women to change their ſhapes, then men their minds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Then men their minds? tis true: oh heuen, were man
But Constant, he were perfect; that one error
Fils him with faults: makes him run through all th’ ſins;
Inconstancy falls-off, ere it begins:
What is in Siluia's face, but I may ſpie
More fresh in Iulia's, with a constant eye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come: a hand from either:
Let me be blest to make this happy close:
'Twere pitty two ſuch friends ſhould be long fœs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare witnes (heauen) I haue my wish for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: And I mine.
Out-l.
A prize: a prize: a prize.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare, forbeare I ſay: It is my Lord the Duke.
Your Grace is welcome to a man disgrac’d,
Banished Valentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thu.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder is Siluia: and Siluia's mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Thurio giue backe; or else embrace thy death:
Come not within the measure of my wrath:
Doe not name Siluia thine: if once againe,
Verona ſhall not hold thee: heere ſhe ſtands,
Take but poſſeſſion of her, with a Touch:
I dare thee, but to breath vpon my Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thur.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I:
I hold him but a foole that will endanger
His Body, for a Girle that loues him not:
I claime her not, and therefore ſhe is thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: The more degenerate and base art thou
To make ſuch meanes for her, as thou hast done,
And leaue her on ſuch ſlight conditions.
Now, by the honor of my Ancestry,
I doe applaud thy ſpirit, Valentine,
And thinke thee worthy of an Empreſſe loue:
Know then, I heere forget all former greefes,
Cancell all grudge, repeale thee home againe,
Plead a new ſtate in thy vn-riual’d merit,
To which I thus ſubscribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a Gentleman, and well deriu’d,
Take thou thy Siluia, for thou hast deseru’d her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I thank your Grace, y gift hath made me happy:
I now beseech you (for your daughters ſake)
To grant one Boone that I ſhall aske of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I grant it (for thine owne) what ere it be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: These banish’d men, that I haue kept withall,
Are men endu’d with worthy qualities:
Forgiue them what they haue committed here,
And let them be recall’d from their Exile:
They are reformed, ciuill, full of good,
And fit for great employment (worthy Lord.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast preuaild, I pardon them and thee:
Dispose of them, as thou knowst their deserts.
Come, let vs goe, we will include all iarres,
With Triumphes, Mirth, and rare ſolemnity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: And as we walke along, I dare be bold
With our discourse, to make your Grace to ſmile.
What thinke you of this Page (my Lord?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I think the Boy hath grace in him, he blushes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant you (my Lord) more grace, then Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: What meane you by that ſaying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Val.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you, Ile tell you, as we paſſe along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned:
Come Protheus, ‘tis your pennance, but to heare
The ſtory of your Loues discouered.
That done, our day of marriage ſhall be yours,
One Feast, one house, one mutuall happineſſe.

PERSONAE.PERSONA: The Names of all the Actors.
Thurio: a foolish riuall to Valentine.
Eglamoure: Agent for Siluia in her escape.
Speed: a clownish ſeruant to Valentine.
